intro.description: Study the needs of the customers you are targeting to, their motivation, their perspectives, etc. The main idea is to understand why they would buy your service and not others. This can be done by interviews, surveys or observation. Once that is clear, explain what the added value of this application is with respect to its competitor. This can be, later on, your sales pitch argument.

item.title: Identify and analyse the customers’ needs and motivation
item.description: Try to understand which is your target market and why each one of them would buy your product.

item.title: Define the functionalities that need to be delivered to each customer segment in order to solve their needs
item.description: If you have identified different market segments and different value propositions for each one of them, you should delimit what you will offer distinctively to each target group. This means, for instance, that the number of functionalities may vary depending on the target group. This can also vary if you decide to apply a tiered business model (e.g. regular user, professional user, enterprise user, etc.).

item.title: Define the value delivered to each customer segment
item.description: Once the customers’ needs for each market segment and the corresponding functionalities to be provided, describe the value proposition specific for each of these segments. Some of the questions you need to be able to answer: What is the added value of this service compared to the one that my competitors are already providing? What am I offering that the others are not? Tip: The value proposition must include what the service is aimed for and how it is different from the competitors. In addition to that, strategic definition of the value proposition, it is recommended to include for each service, the related technical information about the service offerings (capabilities, interface definitions including available service operations and pricing information)
